raw_text:
Day-Lewis set for Berlin honour
 
 Actor Daniel Day-Lewis is to be presented with an award for his career in film at the Berlin Film Festival.
 
 The 47-year-old, whose credits include his Oscar-winning performance in My Left Foot, will be presented with the Berlinale Camera award on 15 February. The honour, awarded since 1986, honours figures in cinema that the festival feels "particularly indebted to". Man to Man, a historical epic starring Kristin Scott Thomas, opens the German festival on 10 February. A candid documentary about the life and career of singer George Michael, A Different Story will also be screened at the 10-day event. '
 
 Day-Lewis has competed four times at the Berlin Film Festival, with films In The Name Of The Father (1994), The Crucible (1997), The Boxer (1998) and Martin Scorsese's Gangs Of New York (2003). The festival praises him for his "sensational start" with roles in My Beautiful Launderette and costume classic A Room With A View, and a "great number of celebrated roles" in subsequent productions. Japan's oldest film studio will also be honoured along with Day-Lewis. Shochiku film studios, which was founded 110 years ago, will become the first cinematic institution to receive the Berlinale Camera award. Famous Japanese directors including Akira Kurosawa have had films produced at the studio.

The text starts by mentioning that Daniel Day-Lewis is being presented with an award for his career in film at the Berlin Film Festival. He's 47 and has had four films there before: In The Name Of The Father, The Crucible, The Boxer, and Martin Scorsese's Gangs of New York.

He's been nominated multiple times for recognition, though I don't know if he won any yet. The Berlinale Camera award is mentioned as a significant honor since 1986. It honors figures in cinema that the festival feels particularly indebted to. The text also talks about other films opening at the festival, like My Man to Man and A Different Story.

Daniel Day-Lewis's career has been noted for his strong start with roles he was nominated for, such as My Beautiful Launderette and A Room With A View, which are classic costume roles. He's been recognized for "great number of celebrated roles" in later films too.

There's also mention that Japan's oldest film studio is being honored along with Day-Lewis, and Shochiku film studios were founded 110 years ago and have produced films there. Japanese directors like Akira Kurosawa are part of this.

Alright, so I need to condense all that into a concise summary without any explanations or formatting. Just the key points about his award, his career roles, other films opening, and the honor received.
</think>

Daniel Day-Lewis is receiving the Berlin Film Festival Camera Award for his film career. He will be honored on 15 February, alongside other notable films, with Japan's oldest film studio also receiving the award. His strong start with "slogan" roles in My Beautiful Launderette and A Room With A View has been praised by the festival, which recognizes figures it considers particularly indebted to. Additionally, Shochiku film studios, established 110 years ago, will gain recognition as they produce films at Berlin's festival.
tinyllama:1.1b: Actress Daniel Day-Lewi is set for an award at the Berlin Film Festival, where he will be honored with the Berlinale Camera award for his career in film since receiving his first credit in My Left Foot. Day-Lewi's films have been widely lauded by the festival, with a "sensational start" from In The Name of the Father and The Boxer, as well as more recent productions like Martin Scorsese's Gangsta's Paradise. Japan's oldest film studio Shochiku is also being recognized in this year's award ceremony. Famous Japanese directors, including Akira Kurosawa, have had films produced at the studio before receiving the Berlinale Camera award for their contributions to cinema.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Berlin Film Festival is set to recognize actor Daniel Day-Lewis with an honor for his career in film, bestowing upon him the Berlinale Camera award. This prestigious prize honors figures that the festival deems "particularly indebted" to cinema, and specifically recognizes performances in films such as My Left Foot (1987) and A Different Story: The Life and Career of George Michael (2016). Additionally, Day-Lewis has competed at the Berlin Film Festival four times in four consecutive years, showcasing a sensational start to his career with roles in films such as In the Name of the Father (1994), The Crucible (1997), and The Boxer (1998). Notable films by his British director colleagues such as Martin Scorsese's Gangs of New York (2003) also receive recognition through this honor. Additionally, this year marks the first time that Shochiku film studios will be honored alongside Day-Lewis, recognizing their long history and contributions to the cinema industry. Notable Japanese directors such as Kurosawa Akira will join the festivities with a special tribute, demonstrating the importance of Japan's cinematic heritage to both the festival and the film industry.
